heading.title: SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF PROCESS ACT 1992 (CTH)

leg:info.leg:officialname: SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF PROCESS ACT 1992 (CTH)

p.text: This Division applies in relation to all warrants other than warrants issued by tribunals.
[s 81 subst Act 143 of 2010 s 3 and Sch 2 item 2, effective 16 June 2011]
In this Part:
includes a body or person that:
under a law of a State, may issue a warrant for the arrest and return to custody or detention of a person, following the revocation or cancellation of:
a parole order; or
an order for conditional release; or
an order for home detention; or
an order for periodic detention; or
any other order for the release of a person from custody; or
any other order of a kind prescribed by the regulations; and
is prescribed by the regulations.
does not include a body or person of a kind referred to in the definition of authority in this section.
includes a warrant issued by a body or person that is an authority for the purposes of this Part.
[s 81A insrt Act 41 of 2003 s 3 and Sch 2 , effective 3 December 2003]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [415,680] s 82 Persons subject to warrants may be apprehended

leg:heading.title: Persons subject to warrants may be apprehended

p.text: Subject to subsection (2) , the person named in a warrant issued in a State may be apprehended in another State.
This section does not apply in relation to a person who is in prison.
The person may be apprehended by:
an officer of the police force of the State in which the person is found; or
the Sheriff of that State, or any of the Sheriff's officers; or
a member or special member of the Australian Federal Police.
[subs (3) am Act 9 of 2000 Sch 2]
It is not necessary to produce the warrant when the person is apprehended.
Even though a person has been released under subsection 83(3) , (4) or (7) , the person may be re-apprehended under the same warrant.
The warrant or a copy of the warrant must be produced when the person is re-apprehended.
As soon as practicable after being apprehended, the person is to be taken before a magistrate of the State in which the person was apprehended.
The warrant or a copy of the warrant must be produced to the magistrate if it is available.
If the warrant or a copy of the warrant is not produced, the magistrate may:
order that the person be released; or
adjourn the proceeding for such reasonable time as the magistrate specifies and remand the person on bail or in such custody as the magistrate specifies.
If the warrant or a copy of the warrant is not produced when the proceeding resumes, the magistrate may:
order that the person be released; or
if reasonable cause is shown, adjourn the proceeding for such further reasonable time as the magistrate specifies and remand the person on bail or in such custody as the magistrate specifies.
The total time of the adjournments referred to in paragraphs (3)(b) and (4)(b) must not exceed 5 days.
The magistrate may resume the proceeding at any time before the end of a period of adjournment if the warrant or a copy of the warrant becomes available.
If the warrant or a copy of the warrant is not produced when the proceeding resumes after the further adjournment, the magistrate must order that the person be released.
Subject to subsections (10) and (14) and section 84 , if the warrant or a copy of the warrant is produced, the magistrate must order:
that the person be remanded on bail on condition that the person appear at such time and place in the place of issue of the warrant as the magistrate specifies; or
that the person be taken, in such custody or otherwise as the magistrate specifies, to a specified place in the place of issue of the warrant.
The order may be subject to other specified conditions.
The magistrate must order that the person be released if the magistrate is satisfied that the warrant is invalid.
The magistrate may suspend an order made under paragraph (8)(b) for a specified period.
On suspending the order, the magistrate must order that the person be remanded:
on bail; or
in such custody as the magistrate specifies;
until the end of that period.
An order of a magistrate under this section may be executed according to its tenor.
For the purposes of a proceeding under this section:
the magistrate may adjourn the proceeding and remand the person on bail, or in such custody as the magistrate specifies, for the adjournment; and
the magistrate is not bound by the rules of evidence; and
it is not necessary that a magistrate before whom the proceeding was previously conducted continue to conduct the proceeding.
Nothing in this section affects the operation of Part IC of the Crimes Act 1914.
Legislation cited in [415,685.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 ss 82, 83.

The corresponding provisions to ss 82 and 83 were contained in ss 18 and 19 of the 1901 Act and were held to be within the constitutional power of the Commonwealth: Aston v Irvine (1955) 92 CLR 353; 29 ALJR 411 .
Legislation cited in [415,685.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 s 83(10), s 83(3) , (4), (5), s 83(7).

The section provides for a more restricted discretion than was the case under s 86 of the 1901 legislation. The Act now requires that if a valid warrant is produced to the magistrate then the person who has been apprehended under the warrant is either to be returned to, or granted bail on the condition that they appear in, the state where the warrant was issued. Where the warrant or copy of the warrant is not produced, the magistrate has a discretion to release the person or remand the person in custody and adjourn the proceedings. Only two adjournments are permitted and they must not total more than five days: s 83(3) , (4) and (5) ; and thereafter the magistrate must release the person: s 83(7) . If the warrant is invalid, the magistrate must order the person be released: s 83(10) . As under the 1901 Act there is no power to investigate the merits of the prosecution case and no requirement for evidence or particulars as to the general nature of the offence charged: Rider v Champness [1971] VR 239 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [415,690] s 84 Additional provisions relating to persons under restraint

leg:heading.title: Additional provisions relating to persons under restraint

p.text: If a person is taken before a magistrate under section 83 , the magistrate must, before dealing with the matter, make reasonable enquiries of the person to find out:
whether he or she is a person under restraint; and
if so, the State or States under whose law he or she is a person under restraint.
[subs (1) am Act 34 of 1997 s 3 and Sch 14]
If the magistrate is satisfied that the person:
is not under restraint; or
is under restraint only under the law of the State in which the warrant was issued;
the following provisions of this section do not apply.
[subs (1A) insrt Act 34 of 1997 s 3 and Sch 14]

If the person informs the magistrate that he or she is on bail, the magistrate must, before dealing with the matter, make reasonable enquiries of the person to ascertain the reporting requirements (if any) to which the person is subject.
The person must not:
fail to answer the magistrate's enquiries under subsection (1) or (2) ; or
intentionally give a false or misleading answer to any of those enquiries.
Penalty: $3000.
[subs (3) am Act 24 of 2001 s 3 and Sch 44, effective 24 May 2001]
If the person under restraint is not on bail:
the magistrate must:
adjourn the proceeding for such reasonable time, not exceeding 7 days, as the magistrate specifies; and
remand the person:
on bail on condition that the person appear when the proceeding resumes; or
in such custody as the magistrate specifies for the time of the adjournment; and

as soon as practicable after the adjournment, cause notice of the person's apprehension to be given, by audio link or fax, to the person in charge of the correction service of the State in which the person is under restraint; and
when the proceeding resumes:
the person so informed; and
a supervisor of the person under restraint;
may make submissions to the magistrate.
[subs (4) am Act 77 of 2009 s 3 and Sch 2[23], effective 7 September 2009]
If the person under restraint is on bail, the magistrate may, on the application of:
any officer of the police force of any State; or
any member or special member of the Australian Federal Police; or
the person under restraint;
adjourn the proceeding for such reasonable time, not exceeding 7 days, as the magistrate specifies.
[subs (5) am Act 9 of 2000 Sch 2]
If the magistrate adjourns the proceeding under subsection (5) :
he or she must:
remand the person under restraint:
on bail on condition that the person appear when the proceeding resumes; or
in such custody as the magistrate specifies for the time of the adjournment; and

if the person is subject to a requirement to report to an officer of a correction service of a State — as soon as practicable after the adjournment, cause notice of the person's apprehension to be given, by audio link or fax, to the person in charge of that correction service; and

if the person is subject to a requirement to report to the police in a State other than the State in which he or she is apprehended — as soon as practicable after the adjournment, cause notice of the person's apprehension to be given, by audio link or fax, to a police officer at the police station at which the person is required to report; and
when the proceeding resumes:
the person's supervisor; and
any officer of the police force of any State; and
any member or special member of the Australian Federal Police;
may make submissions to the magistrate.
[subs (6) am Act 9 of 2000 Sch 2; Act 77 of 2009 s 3 and Sch 2[23]effective 7 September 2009]

If a person under restraint who is named in a warrant is remanded on bail under an order made under paragraph 83(8)(a) , it is a condition to which the grant of bail is subject that the person must return as soon as practicable to the State in which he or she was under restraint.

Where an order is made under paragraph 83(8)(b) in relation to a person under restraint, a magistrate may make orders relating to the return of the person, in such custody or otherwise as the magistrate specifies, to the State in which he or she was under restraint.
The regulations may provide that, for the purposes of this section, the holder of a specified office in a State is taken to be the person in charge of the correction service of the State.
In this section:

, in relation to a person under restraint, means a person who, under the law of a State or the order of a court, supervises compliance with the order or restriction to which the person under restraint is subject.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [415,695] s 85 Procedure on remand on bail

p.text: If a magistrate has made an order under paragraph 83(8)(a) or (12)(a) , the magistrate must prepare, or cause to be prepared, an instrument setting out the conditions to which the grant of bail is subject.
The instrument must be signed by:
the magistrate, or the person who prepared the instrument; and
the person who is the subject of the order.
The person, and the court, authority, tribunal or person before which or whom the person has been remanded to appear, must each be given a copy of the instrument.
The magistrate must revoke the order and make an order under paragraph 83(8)(b) or (12)(b) if the person:
refuses to sign the instrument; or
does not comply with a condition to which the grant of bail is subject and that condition is a condition precedent to the person's release on bail.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [415,700] s 85A Notification when persons are released or remanded on bail

leg:heading.title: Notification when persons are released or remanded on bail

p.text: If the person named in the warrant has been:
taken before a magistrate under section 83 ; and

the Commissioner of the police force of which the police officer who apprehended the person is a member must cause the clerk of the court that issued the warrant, or the authority that issued the warrant, to be notified without delay of the release or remand.
As soon as practicable after being so notified, the clerk, or the authority, must notify the police force of each other State that was notified of the issue of the warrant that:

if the person has been released under paragraph 83(3)(a) , or (4)(a) or subsection 83(7) — that the person has been released and can only be re-apprehended if the warrant or a copy of the warrant is produced when the person is re-apprehended; or
in any other case — that the warrant has been executed.
[s 85A insrt Act 141 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 1]

If an order has been made under section 83 , the apprehended person or a person to whom the warrant was directed may apply to the Supreme Court of the State in which the order was made for review of the order.
The application must be made within 7 days after the making of the order.
The respondent is to be:
if the application is made by the apprehended person — the Commissioner of the police force of the State in which the person was apprehended; or
if the application is made by a person to whom the warrant was directed — the apprehended person.
Service of the notice of application on the respondent must be effected in the same way as service of a notice of an appeal to the Supreme Court of the State in a criminal proceeding.
If, under the order, the apprehended person is remanded on bail, notice of the application must be served in the same way on any person providing surety for the granting of the bail.
The Supreme Court may, pending its review:
stay the execution of the order; and
order the person to be remanded on bail or in such custody as the Supreme Court specifies.
The review is to be by way of rehearing.
The Supreme Court may confirm, vary or revoke the order.
If the order is revoked, the Supreme Court may make a new order.
The Supreme Court may suspend an order for a specified period if it is an order of a kind that a magistrate may suspend under section 83 .
The order as confirmed or varied, or the new order, may be executed according to its tenor.
If the order as confirmed or varied, or the new order, is an order that is similar to an order mentioned in paragraph 83(8)(a) :
the Supreme Court must cause an instrument of the type mentioned in subsection 85(1) to be prepared; and
subject to subsection (13) , subsections 85(2) , (3) and (4) apply.
For the purposes of paragraph (12)(b) :
the reference in paragraph 85(2)(a) to a magistrate is taken to be omitted; and
the reference in subsection 85(4) to a magistrate is a reference to the Supreme Court.
For the purposes of a review under this section, the Supreme Court of a State is not bound by the rules of evidence.
Legislation cited in [415,705.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 s 83, s 86, s 86(2), s 90.

The power to review extends to considering the validity of a warrant, which if invalid, may be revoked: Gummer v Cmr of Police (Qld) (QCA, 21 March 1994, unreported) . The power under s 83 and on review under s 86 , is precisely delineated. Apart from the power to grant bail conferred by s 90 , there is no discretionary judgment — as there was under s 18(6) and, on review, under s 19 , of the 1901 Act — to refuse to return the person served to the place of issue of the warrant. However, a Supreme Court has an original jurisdiction to set aside an order for extradition on the ground of oppression or unfairness: Lavelle v Cmr of Police (WASC, Murray J, No 2269 of 1993, 13 May 1994, unreported) . Section 86 is intended to cover the field of proceedings or steps to challenge an order under s 83 : Re Dalton's Application (VSC, Batt J, 27 September 1995, unreported) . The time limit prescribed by s 86(2) is mandatory and may not be extended under any power of extension conferred by Rules of Court: ibid.
This section applies to a warrant issued for the purpose of having a person attend before a court, authority or person to give evidence or produce a document or thing.
Subject to subsection (3) , a person who has incurred reasonable expenses as a result of compliance (by that person or another person) with:
an order of a magistrate under subsection 83(8) in relation to a person brought before the magistrate under a warrant to which this section applies; or
is entitled to payment, from the person at whose request the warrant was issued, of an amount equal to those expenses.
Subsection (2) does not apply if:
the warrant was issued because of a person's failure to comply with a subpoena; and
that person:
is not a person under restraint; or
is a person under restraint who has failed to comply with section 36.
The court or authority that issued the warrant may make orders to ensure that the person who incurred those expenses receives the exact amount of those expenses.
If the warrant was issued by a court, the orders may be made by an officer of the court if the rules governing the procedure of the court so provide.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [415,715] s 88 Law applicable to grant etc of bail

leg:heading.title: Law applicable to grant etc of bail

p.text: Despite subsection 68(1) of the Judiciary Act 1903, the law of a State with respect to the granting of bail applies in relation to a power under this Division to grant bail to:
a person apprehended in that State; or
as if the person had been apprehended under, or by authority of, a law of that State.

The law of a State with respect to bail and matters related to bail (including enforcement of bail) applies in relation to a person who has been remanded on bail in that State under this Division as if the person had been remanded on bail to appear before a court of that State.
Money received in proceedings for the enforcement of bail is to be retained by the State in which the bail condition, the breach of which lead to the proceedings being brought, was imposed.

For the purpose of complying with an order made under paragraph 83(8)(b) , or an order confirmed, varied or made under section 86 that is similar to an order mentioned in that paragraph, the person to whom the custody of the apprehended person has been committed may require that the person in charge of a prison in a State:
receive the apprehended person and keep the apprehended person in custody for such time as the first-mentioned person requires; and
surrender custody of the apprehended person to the first-mentioned person at the time and in the way that the first-mentioned person requires.
The person so required must comply with such requirements as are reasonable.

An apprehended person who is a person under restraint and who is serving a period of home detention or a term of imprisonment by way of periodic detention is taken to be serving that period of home detention or term of imprisonment:
during the period commencing when the person is apprehended under section 82 and ending when the person is first taken before a magistrate under section 83 ; and
during any period during which the person is in custody under an order made under paragraph 83(3)(b) , (4)(b) , (8)(b) or (12)(b) , paragraph 86(6)(b) or subsection 86(9) .

The law in force in the place of issue of a warrant, being the law relating to the liability of a person who escapes from lawful custody, applies to a person being taken to the place of issue in compliance with an order mentioned in subsection (1) .
Subsection (4) does not apply to lawful custody in respect of an offence against a law of the Commonwealth.
A reference in this section to an order made under paragraph 83(8)(b) includes a reference to an order made under subsection 84(8) that relates to the first-mentioned order.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [415,725] s 90 Release of persons unnecessarily detained

p.text: This section applies to a person who has been taken in custody, pursuant to an order made, confirmed or varied under this Division, to the place of issue of a warrant for the purpose of giving evidence or producing a document or thing.
The person may apply to the court of issue, or authority of issue, of the warrant for an order that he or she be released from custody.
The respondent is to be the person at whose request the warrant was issued.
Notice of the application must be served on the respondent:
personally; or
by sending it by post to his or her address for service in the proceeding in relation to which the warrant was issued; or
by sending it by fax to that address; or
by leaving a copy of the application at that address.

The court of issue, or authority of issue, of the warrant may order that the person be released from custody if it is satisfied that it is not necessary for the person to be held in custody in order to secure his or her attendance to give the evidence or produce the document or thing.
Upon such an order being made, the person is to be released.

The court of issue, or authority of issue, of the warrant may further order that the person be remanded on bail on condition that he or she appear, at a specified time or day, before the court, authority, tribunal or person to which the evidence is to be given or the document or thing is to be produced.
